column1: West End Girls is a song by the English synth-pop duo Pet Shop Boys. Written by Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe
column2: the song was released twice as a single. The song's lyrics are concerned with class and the pressures of inner-city life which were inspired partly by T. S. Eliot's poem The Waste Land. It was generally well received by contemporary music critics and has been frequently cited as a highlight in the duo's career.

column1: The first version of the song was produced by Bobby Orlando and was released on Columbia Records' Bobcat Records imprint in April 1984
column2: becoming a club hit in the United States and some European countries. After the duo signed with EMI
column3: the song was re-recorded with producer Stephen Hague for their first studio album
column6: reaching number one in the United Kingdom and the United States in 1986.

column2: the song won Best Single at the Brit Awards
column3: and Best International Hit at the Ivor Novello Awards. In 2005
column5: the song was awarded Song of The Decade between the years 1985 and 1994 by the British Academy of Composers and Songwriters. A critic's poll by  The Guardian selected "West End Girls" as number one of the 100 greatest UK number one singles in 2020.The song was performed by Pet Shop Boys at the 2012 Summer Olympics closing ceremony.

column1: West End Girls is a synthpop song influenced by hip hop music. The song's socially conscious streak
column2: as well as the propulsive bass line
column3: derives from Grandmaster Flash's protest rap song "The Message". Lowe and Hague created a "snaky
column4: obsessive rhythm punch" for the music
column5: replacing the song's previously sparse beats and minimal keyboard lines.Tennant started to write the song when he was staying at his cousin's house in Nottingham while watching a gangster film. Just when he was going to sleep he came up with the lines: "Sometimes you're better off dead
column6: there's a gun in your hand and it's pointing at your head". The lyrics were inspired by T.S. Eliot's poem The Waste Land
column7: particularly in the use of different narrative voices and arcane references. The song's lyrics are largely concerned with class
column8: inner-city pressure. Tennant later said that some listeners had assumed the song referred to prostitutes
column10: "about rough boys getting a bit of posh."The lyric "From Lake Geneva to the Finland Station" refers to the train route taken by Vladimir Lenin when he was smuggled by the Germans to Russia during World War I
column11: a pivotal event in the Russian Revolution. Indeed
column12: it is highly likely the lyric was inspired by the book To the Finland Station by Edmund Wilson
column13: a famous work on the history of revolutionary thought and Socialism that Tennant would have at least heard of
column15: as a student. The Bobby Orlando-produced version of the single included another line

column1: West End Girls has been generally well received by music critics. Stephen Thomas Erlewine from Allmusic in a review of the album Please called the song "hypnotic"
column2: adding that "it's not only a classic dance single
column3: it's a classic pop single". In a review for the group's second studio album Actually
column4: Rob Hoerburger from Rolling Stone magazine commented that "West End Girls" was "as catchy as anything on the radio in 1986"
column5: praising "its enticing bass line and foreboding synth riffs"
column6: but felt that it was almost "nullified by peevish spoken asides and the cryptic posturing of the duo's lyrics". In a review of the live album Concrete
column7: Michael Hubbard from musicOMH said that "West End Girls" was one of the songs that "round out a collection that never feels too long or superfluous"
column8: adding that it "goes some way to installing Tennant and Lowe as national treasures".Nitsuh Abebe from Pitchfork Media
column9: in a review of their compilation album PopArt: Pet Shop Boys - The Hits commented that in the song "we meet Tennant not as a singer
column11: adding that "he mumbles the verses to us not like a star
column12: but like a stranger in a raincoat
column13: slinking alongside you and pointing out the sights".In 1987
column14: "West End Girls" won for Best Single at The BRIT Awards
column15: and for Best International Hit at the Ivor Novello Awards. In 2005
column16: the British Academy of Composers and Songwriters gave to West End Girls the Ivor Novello Award for Song of The Decade between the years 1985 and 1994.In 2015 the song was voted by the British public as the nation's 12th favourite 1980s number one in a poll for ITV. In 2020 The Guardian selected "West End Girls" as number one in a critics' poll of the 100 greatest UK number one singles.

column1: The video was directed by Andy Morahan and Eric Watson
column2: and consists of shots of the duo around London. At the beginning of the video
column3: noises from the city can be heard
column4: a camera passes Lowe on the street
column5: and focuses on two vintage dolls in a shop window. Then appears a sequence of quick cuts with shots of the city's different sub-cultures; the video freezes and cuts to Tennant and Lowe
column6: who walk through an empty Wentworth Street in Petticoat Lane Market. They stand in front of a red garage door; Tennant is in front dressed with a long coat
column9: with Lowe standing behind him with a blank expression. Lowe is filmed in double-exposure and appears almost ghostlike. In other shots
column10: Tennant power-walks imperiously while Lowe casually follows behind. While Tennant delivers the lyrics & chorus directly at the viewer
column11: Lowe appears at times disinterested in the proceedings or preoccupied with other goings-on around them.

column8: with the Houses of Parliament as a background.The camera shows shots of young women
column9: and passes through arcades and cinemas in Leicester Square. The camera now passes South Africa House showing protestors in the Non-Stop Picket

column1: West End Girls was first released in April 1984 through writer and producer Bobby Orlando's label. The song was a club hit in the United States
column4: where it debuted at number 24 on the VRT Top 30 chart on 28 July 1984
column5: peaking at 17 four weeks later. In Canada
column6: "West End Girls" first entered the RPM singles chart in April 1985
column7: reaching a peak position of 81 in June 1985.Having signed with EMI
column8: the group released their first major label single "Opportunities (Let's Make Lots of Money)" in mid-1985
column9: but it failed to attract attention. The Pet Shop Boys then decided to re-record "West End Girls"
column10: and issue this new version as a single. Producer Stephen Hague helmed the new
column11: re-recorded version of "West End Girls".The re-recorded version of "West End Girls" was released in the United Kingdom in October 1985
column12: debuting on the UK Singles Chart at number 80
column13: and within eight weeks of its release it had reached the top of the chart. It maintained the number one position for two weeks and received a gold certification by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) in January 1986. Across Europe
column14: "West End Girls" also topped the singles chart in Norway
column15: as well as peaking in the top three in Belgium
column21: where the original recording of "West End Girls" had already been a minor hit in 1985
column22: the re-recorded version was issued as a single in early 1986. The re-recorded song entered the chart in March 1986
column23: peaking at number one for one week on 17 May 1986. In the United States
column24: West End Girls debuted on the Billboard Hot 100 at number 71
column25: reaching the number one position on 10 May 1986
column26: and remained on the chart for 20 weeks. The song also peaked at number one on Billboard's Hot Dance Music/Club Play chart for two weeks.
